question: Is Rupert Murdoch a fit person to run an international media corporation?

content.source_1: UK Parliament Culture, Media and Sport Committee (2012) — “News International and phone-hacking” report concluded: “Rupert Murdoch is not a fit person to exercise the stewardship of a major international company,” citing failures of governance and oversight at News International during the phone-hacking scandal. Source: https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201012/cmselect/cmcumeds/903/90302.htm
content.source_2: Ofcom (2012) — Following an extensive “fit and proper” assessment in the wake of phone hacking, the UK broadcast regulator found BSkyB “remains a fit and proper holder of a broadcast licence,” while criticizing James Murdoch’s conduct. This indicates regulators did not deem the Murdoch-controlled broadcaster unfit to operate. Source: https://www.ofcom.org.uk/about-ofcom/latest/features-and-news/statement-fit-and-proper-bskyb
content.source_3: Delaware Superior Court/Dominion v. Fox News (2023) — On the eve of trial, Fox agreed to a $787.5 million settlement after the judge ruled the challenged statements about Dominion were false; deposition materials showed Rupert Murdoch acknowledged some Fox hosts “endorsed” false election claims. This raises questions about standards and oversight at a Murdoch-led outlet. Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/18/business/media/fox-news-dominion-settlement.html
content.source_4: The Leveson Inquiry report (2012) — The UK judge-led inquiry into press culture found serious failures at News International, including “significant failure of corporate governance,” documenting systemic ethical lapses under Murdoch’s ownership even if not attributing criminal liability to him personally. Source: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/leveson-inquiry-report-into-the-culture-practices-and-ethics-of-the-press
content.source_5: Pulitzer Prizes — The Wall Street Journal (owned by Murdoch’s News Corp) won the 2019 Pulitzer Prize for National Reporting, among other awards, reflecting sustained high-quality journalism produced under Murdoch’s ownership and suggesting capability to steward major newsrooms. Source: https://www.pulitzer.org/winners/staff-wall-street-journal-0
content.source_6: Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) advisory (2012) — Proxy adviser ISS urged News Corp investors to vote against Rupert Murdoch’s re-election as chairman, citing governance and oversight concerns post–phone hacking. This reflects investor-side doubts about his suitability to lead. Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-newscorp-iss-idUSBRE89C02D20121013
